Apr 14

How catering services in trains cheat you and make a killing on Rajdhani/Shatabdi/Durnoto/Super AC class trains in India

My love for planned yet spontaneous journeys has been the reason why I frequently choose to travel by Rajdhani, Shatabdi and Super AC trains of the Indian Railways. Having food served at your berth during the whole length of the journey is relaxing, giving me time to talk to people and focus on my reading, typing and pondering about the next start-up idea. Several years back, while I used to travel on the Trivandrum Rajdhani from Kochi to Kota and back, the food trays had the menu card placed on it so that the passengers were informed about the menu.

I boarded Train No: 22207 from Chennai Central towards Ernakulam on Tuesday (11/4/2017), paying a ticket charge close to 1900 INR (due to dynamic pricing) for my third AC berth. By the time I settled on my berth, I was drenched in sweat as the Chennai heat was not kind to me and the bags were heavy. A sense of relaxation crept in knowing that I am going to get juice and a water bottle while I cool down in the AC train. After waiting for a few minutes, I got my water bottle and I did drink from it but my thirst was not quenched. It was alright, I thought, as it would allow me to devour the taste of the juice (silently I wished that it was cold). Later, I was served my evening snacks as per the menu (though not complete) and still they did not give me the juice which was supposed to be a part of my welcome drink and a part of my evening snack. I then politely asked the attendant about it and he said he does not have it. At that point, I was a bit furious and I knew that venting my frustration out at him will be futile, which was when I took it to Twitter for a solution as I had read in the news that these days IRCTC is very responsive when it comes to Twitter complaints. I tweeted what happened with the IRCTC twitter handle and waited.

Within 30 minutes the IRCTC handle responded by saying that they would look into the matter and let me know. The promptness took me by surprise. They requested my PNR number for further clarifications, I shared it and skeptically waited.

Just after I had my dinner and was preparing myself for the night, the person who takes care of complaints and grievances on the train came. He asked “Are you 48, Ernakulam, Twitter?” I said “Yes.” He told me that the juice does not exist on the menu and it is only for 1st class passengers. Even when I showed him the menu which was displayed on the IRCTC website, he argued saying that the IRCTC website was wrong, he was not informed about it and that he had served everything on the menu. After a small talk, he did bring the juice for me, following which he requested me to take down the tweet. I didn’t.

Here comes the funny part, they still got it wrong. They served a 150 ml juice when it was supposed to be 200 ml. They avoided the eclairs, took off the welcome drink procedure all together and just gave a bottle of water. You should also remember that, they only gave the juice to me and to no one else.

From what I have understood, the “Welcome Menu“ means, whenever you board the train, you are supposed to be served. Assuming nobody in any of the coaches received it, let’s do the math.

  • Number of coaches — 8 for 3rd AC and 3 for 2nd AC
  • Number of people per coach — 64 in 3rd AC and 46 in 2nd AC
  • Total people — 650

Items Missing

  • Juice — 2 (Welcome drink and evening snack) INR 24
  • Eclairs — 2 X 2 (Welcome drink and evening snack) INR 4
  • Butter- 1 (Part of the soup) INR 5
  • Biscuit — 1 (Welcome drink) INR 5 (approx)
  • Creamer — (Evening snack; they provided milk, so let us chuck it)
  • Salad — (Dinner) INR 5 ( approx)
  • Pickle — 1 (Dinner) 2 INR (approx)
  • Salt and pepper — 1 (Dinner) 1 INR

In the menu card which was published, it was mentioned that they were supposed to give stainless steel cutlery but we were provided with plastic spoons.

Total = 650 X 46 = INR 29,900 (approximate)

What Happened Post Issue

When I was writing this article, I saw a lady getting scammed right in front of me. The attendant demanded 20 rupees for the water bottle which was supposed to be inclusive, demanding 5 rupees more than the MRP. He justified his actions by saying that it was not his duty to provide the water bottle. Just then, the TT had come in. I had a good chat with him and he agreed such things do happen as the private players were always trying to gain more profit. He also said that he had no say in such matters and told me to use twitter as it was an effective medium for addressing complaints.

I would like to bring to notice about a similar incident which happened a few months back when I asked for the juice on a Shatabdi train from Chennai to Bangalore. The attendant screamed at me for enquiring about it.

Suggestion to All Passengers

The public needs to know what they are paying for. The private caterers are saving a lot of money while taking a huge premium from the travellers. I noticed that the Indian Railways is trying to bring about a change. I respect it. It has been ages since I have paid more than the MRP for any product at the railways station (though I have doubts regarding afew things they sell on trains, I just avoid them).

Suggestions to IRCTC

  • While booking the ticket, the menu for the trip should be attached with the ticket.
  • The passenger should be given the menu card at the start of the journey which must be signed and collected by the authorities after the journey to confirm that they have received what they paid for.

On a Side Note

The cleaning of the train was outsourced to another company and they had done a pretty good job at it. Though, I felt that they had done way too good a job because there were so many people walking around the place and it was a bit difficult to clean due to the crowd. Then again, I am happy that that was done and the toilets and the premises were clean and well maintained. Hygiene is more important than convenience any day.

Whenever I travel in such trains, the attendants always ask for a tip right after dinner, at least this time they did not demand it. I don’t find this happening on Shatabdi trains, only on long distance ones.

Adding to all of this, my friend whom I met on the train advised me not to blog or tweet regarding this matter as the people who handle the catering have ‘goondas’ who will create problems for me. Should the public fear all this? Should we demand what is right?

PFA Menu card (There are some disparities between the menu cards)
